raw_text:
Millions buy MP3 players in US
 
 One in 10 adult Americans - equivalent to 22 million people - owns an MP3 player, according to a survey.
 
 A study by the Pew Internet and American Life Project found that MP3 players are the gadget of choice among affluent young Americans. The survey did not interview teenagers but it is likely that millions of under-18s also have MP3 players. The American love affair with digital music players has been made possible as more and more homes get broadband.
 
 Of the 22 million Americans who own MP3 players, 59% are men compared to 41% of women. Those on high income - judged to be $75,000 (£39,000) or above - are four times more likely to have players than those earning less than $30, 000 ( £15,000). Broadband access plays a big part in ownership too. Almost a quarter of those with broadband at home have players, compared to 9% of those who have dial-up access. MP3 players are still the gadget of choice for younger adults. Almost one in five US citizens aged under 30 have one. This compares to 14% of those aged 30-39 and 14% of those aged 40-48. The influence of children also plays a part. Sixteen percent of parents living with children under 18 have digital players compared to 9% of those who don't. The ease of use and growth of music available on the net are the main factors for the upsurge in ownership, the survey found. People are beginning to use them as instruments of social activity - sharing songs and taking part in podcasting - the survey found. "IPods and MP3 players are becoming a mainstream technology for consumers" said Lee Rainie, director of the Pew Internet and American Life Project. "More growth in the market is inevitable as new devices become available, as new players enter the market, and as new social uses for iPods/MP3 players become popular," he added.
llama3.2:1b: Millions of adult Americans own an MP3 player, with 22 million people accounting for one in 10 ownership.
Men are more likely to own them than women (59% vs 41%).
High-income individuals and those with broadband access at home are also more likely to own players.
Broadband is not as common among those who do not have it.
Many young adults, especially under-30s, own MP3 players due to ease of use and growth of music on the internet.

Those on high income and with broadband at home are more likely to have a player.
Almost one in five US citizens under 30 use an MP3 player, compared to 14% of those aged 30-39.
The ease of use and growth of music available online contribute to the surge in ownership, with people using players as instruments of social activity.

Younger adults are particularly enthusiastic about MP3 players.
Ease of use, online music availability, and social activity contribute to their popularity.

Broadband access to the internet plays a significant role in ownership as almost a quarter of people with broadband have MP3 players.
These devices are becoming popular for sharing music and podcasting - new uses become available every day.
The study suggests that more users will come online, which is expected to increase the market size of digital media.

Over a quarter of broadband users own players compared to only 9% of dial-up users.
Younger adults aged under 30 (18%) are most likely to own MP3 players, with parents of children under 18 also owning them at higher rates (16%).
Ease of use and increased online music availability drive adoption.
The survey found that IPods and MP3 players are increasingly used for social activities like sharing songs and podcasting, indicating a mainstream technology trend.

deepseek-r1:1.5b: Millions buy MP3 players in the US, with one in 10 adult Americans owning at least one.
A survey found that over 22 million people own an MP3 player, including those under 18, making up approximately 59% of owners by gender (men: 59%, women: 41%).
High-income earners (over $75k annually) are four times more likely to own an MP3 player than those earning less than $30k.
Broadband access is crucial, with about a quarter of users owning it compared to dial-up access users at 9%.
Younger adults still dominate but growth rates slowed in the past five years.
Children and parents with young children also use them, with 16% of parents in this age range having digital players.
Socializing through music has grown significantly, influenced by their role as active social media influencers for younger generations.
tinyllama:1.1b: Unleashing the digital music lovers among affluent young Americans with an MP3 player, a survey conducted by Pew Internet and American Life Project reveals that more than 20 million people in America have one as their favorite device.
Men account for over half of all MP3 users, while women follow closely, with men making up 59% of them compared to 41% of women.
Those earning $75,000 or above are four times more likely to have a player than those below the $30,000 threshold.
Broadband access is vital in ownership, with almost a quarter of users having access at home, while nearly one-in-five adults aged under 30 own an MP3 player.
Parents also have digital players, but they're less likely to use them compared to those without kids in the household.
The ease of using and social uses for iPod devices are what are driving growth in the market, with new device launches and popular social uses expected to increase its popularity further.

Broadband usage is also more common among younger age groups, where almost a quarter have an MP3 player.
Overall, the influence of children on digital media usage may be increasing, but so too are social activities using the technology, with podcasting being a popular example.

Broadband access plays a significant role in ownership, along with the ease of use and availability of music on the net.
Children also influence the purchase of digital players, with sixteen percent of parents living with children under 18 having them.
The survey suggests that MP3 players have become a mainstream technology for consumers and will see more growth in the market as new devices and social uses are discovered.

Internet access and social uses for iPods/MP3 players also play a role in ownership.
The survey found that younger generations, particularly those under 30, have a higher usage of MP3 players compared to older adults.
The influence of children also impacts the number of MP3 player owners among parents with young children.

The main factors contributing to the growth in ownership include the ease of use, available music on the internet, and new devices entering the market.

The influence of children also plays a part; parents are using iPods as instruments of social activity - sharing songs and participating in podcasting.

Lee Rainie, director of the Pew Internet and American Life Project, believes that the growth will continue since new devices become available, new players enter the market, and as new social uses for iPods/MP3 players become popular.

Men (59%) and high-income earners (four times more likely) are overrepresented in this group.
The majority of under-30s own MP3 players (41%), while ownership decreases with age.
Parents with children under 18 are also more likely to have digital players (16%) than those without such households (9%).
Factors driving the popularity include ease of use, abundant online music, and emerging social uses like sharing songs and podcasting.

According to Lee Rainie, director of Pew Internet and American Life Project, MP3 players are transitioning into mainstream consumer technology, with continued growth expected as new devices and social uses emerge.
chatgpt-4o-latest: One in 10 adult Americans, or 22 million people, own an MP3 player, according to a Pew Internet and American Life Project survey.
MP3 players are especially popular among affluent young adults, with ownership more common among men (59%) than women (41%).
High-income individuals are four times more likely to own one than those with lower incomes, and broadband access significantly increases ownership rates.
Younger adults, particularly those under 30, are the primary users, and parents with children under 18 are more likely to own one.
The rise in MP3 player ownership is driven by broadband expansion, ease of use, and the growing availability of digital music.
People are increasingly using them for social activities like sharing songs and podcasting.
The survey suggests MP3 players are becoming mainstream, with further market growth expected as new devices and social uses emerge.
